questions.question_text:
Express each number as a product of its prime factors:
(i) 140
(ii) 156
(iii) 3825
(iv) 5005
(v) 7429
hints: Use factor tree or repeated division method
Write each number as product of prime powers
Check divisibility by small primes (2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19)

questions.question_text:
Find the LCM and HCF of the following pairs of integers and verify that LCM × HCF = product of the two numbers.
(i) 26 and 91
(ii) 510 and 92
(iii) 336 and 54
hints: First find prime factorization of each number
HCF = product of smallest powers of common primes
LCM = product of greatest powers of all primes
Verify LCM × HCF = product of numbers

questions.question_text:
Find the LCM and HCF of the following integers by applying the prime factorisation method.
(i) 12, 15 and 21
(ii) 17, 23 and 29
(iii) 8, 9 and 25
hints: For three numbers, HCF = product of smallest powers of common primes
LCM = product of greatest powers of all primes
Note: For prime numbers, HCF = 1 and LCM = product
Use formula: HCF × LCM = product of numbers
Verify using prime factorization if needed

questions.question_text: Check whether 6n can end with the digit 0 for any natural number n.
hints: A number ends with 0 if divisible by 10
10 = 2 × 5, so need both 2 and 5 in prime factors
Analyze prime factors of 6n = (2×3)n
Check if 5 appears in factorization

questions.question_text: Explain why 7 × 11 × 13 + 13 and 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 + 5 are composite numbers.
hints: Factor out common terms
Show both have factors other than 1 and themselves

questions.question_text: There is a circular path around a sports field. Sonia takes 18 minutes to drive one round of the field, while Ravi takes 12 minutes for the same. Suppose they both start at the same point and at the same time, and go in the same direction. After how many minutes will they meet again at the starting point?
hints: Find LCM of 18 and 12
They meet when both complete integer rounds
LCM gives time when both are at starting point simultaneously

questions.question_text:
Prove that the following are irrationals:
(i) 1/√2
(ii) 7√5
(iii) 6 + √2
hints: (i) Assume rational, then √2 = 1/(rational) → contradiction
(ii) Assume rational, then √5 = rational/7 → contradiction
(iii) Assume rational, then √2 = rational - 6 → contradiction
